title: How 2020 Democrats are navigating the impeachment inquiry
text:
Sean Sullivan tracks how Democratic presidential candidates are responding to the impeachment inquiry. Wesley Lowery unpacks the argument for reparations. And Anna Fifield explains how pork prices are overshadowing China’s national day celebrations.

Post Reports is the daily podcast from The Washington Post. Unparalleled reporting. Expert insight. Clear analysis. Everything you’ve come to expect from the newsroom of The Post -- for your ears.

2020 Democrats try to strike a balance on impeachment

The launch of an impeachment inquiry against President Trump has scrambled Democratic presidential campaigns, as candidates work to balance their responses to the scandal with more messaging about the policies that set them apart.





“On the one hand, they are trying to respond to rising concerns that Democratic voters have about President Trump’s conduct,” national politics reporter Sean Sullivan says. “At the same time, they’re still trying to talk about the issues, health care, climate change, income inequality — the kitchen table issues.”

There’s a case for reparations, but how would they work?

The Democratic presidential primary contest has amplified efforts by black academics and activists to steer the national conversation around reparations — the most mainstream discussion of reparations since post-Civil War Reconstruction.

A majority of Americans oppose paying monetary reparations to the descendants of slaves, polls show. But support for such a measure has doubled since the early 2000s, leaving those who agree to answer a critical question: Who would be eligible to receive payouts?





National reporter Wesley Lowery connected with an academic at the forefront of the conversation who has advocated for reparations to people who prove they descended from a person enslaved in the United States and that they have identified as black in public documents for at least 10 years.





“The idea here was that black Americans and specifically Americans who were the descendants of slaves have faced structural impediments that have not allowed them to accumulate wealth,” Lowery says. “And, therefore, the United States government has to make them whole in some kind of way.”

During the Chinese zodiac year of the pig, a pork shortage

Red fried pork. Glazed pork belly. Pork dumplings. In these and other forms, China consumes half the world’s pork, its people eating an average of 120 pounds of pork yearly.





But with a slew of holidays coming up, and the commemoration of the 70th anniversary of the founding of the People’s Republic of China, officials are worried that a staggering pork shortage could destabilize the country’s politics.





“The government is extremely worried that Chinese people will be unhappy when they return to their hometowns and get ready for family feasts, and discover that the price of pork has risen so much that it’s unaffordable,” Beijing bureau chief Anna Fifield says. “This may have political ramifications for them that are not just about being able to have a feast on the national day.”
